questions.text:
Out of the below given investigations, which would be preferred for diagnosing unicornuate uterus?
A. Hysterosalpingography
B. X-Ray
C. Laparoscopy
D. Falloposcopy
questions.solution:
HSG: Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is mainly preferred in uterine anomalies but it cannot distinguish between a septate and bicornuate uterus. This is because in order to distinguish between the two, uterine fundus should be visible.

In Bicornuate uterus the 2 halves of mullerian duct do not fuse and there is defect in fusion of fundus as well.In septate uterus a septum passes down from the uterine fundus. The fundus is normal in appearance.

Note: Kindly see color plates for HSG appearances of various anomalies

  • IOC: MRI followed by 3 dimension USG
  • Gold Standard - Laparoscopy

questions.text: Beta hCG is structurally and functionally similar to:
questions.solution:
• hCG is a glycoprotein. Its molecular weight is 36,000- 40,000 daltons. It consists of a hormone nonspecific alpha (92 amino acids) and a hormone specific beta (145 amino acids) subunit.
  • hCG is chemically and functionally similar to pituitary luteinizing hormone.
  • The alpha subunit is biochemically similar to LH, FSH and TSH whereas the beta subunit is relatively unique to hCG.

questions.text: Uterocervical length in an adult woman is

What is the order a Pap smear is taken?
A. Insert vaginal wall retractor
B. Fix the slide
C. Scrape the ectocervix
D. Prepare the smear
questions.solution:
Pap Smear(Exfoliative Cytology)

  • Time for initiating pap smear: 21 years of age regardless of the age of first sexual-intercourse.

Instrument used: Ayres spatula and endocervical brush

Method: Ayres spatula is rotated through 360° over portio vaginalis of cervix and 1st slide is prepared

  • With cytobrush, 2nd slide is prepared from endocervix
  • Control slide prepared from posterior wall/posterior fornix of vagina

Fixative used: 95% ethyl alcohol and ether.

Note: Liquid base cytology is being used now a days. Preservative used in liquid based cytology is Methanol.

If liquid based cytology is being done it should be repeated every 2 years till female is 30 years of age then 3 yearly.

  • Screening guidelines for cancer cervix are formulated by American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology (ASCCP) and have been revised by the American College of Obs and Gynae in.

questions.text:
Consider these symptoms
A. Dysmenorrhea
B. Infertility
C. Irregular menstruation
D. Vaginal discharge
Which of these are seen in endometriosis?
questions.solution:
ENDOMETRIOSIS

Clinical Features

  • May be asymptomatic
  • M/c symptom is secondary dysmenorrhea commencing after 30 years and gradually increasing
  • Dyspareunia occurs when pouch of douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved
  • Deep-seated pelvic pain
  • Premenstrual and postmenstrual spotting
  • Infertility: 30-40% of patients with endometriosis will be infertile
  • 15-30% of those who are infertile will have

Examination Findings

  • Fixed retroversion of uterus
  • Firm fixed adnexal mass (endometrioma)
  • Tender nodularity of uterine ligaments and cul-de-sac felt on rectovaginal examination

Mnemonic: The 7 Ds of Endometriosis

  1. Dysmenorrhoea
  2. Dyspareunia
  3. Dyschezia
  4. Dysuria
  5. Difficulty in conception (infertility)
  6. Dysfunctional uterine bleeding
  7. Diffuse abdominal pain

FOGSI Focus Guidelines on Endometriosis

questions.text: Identify the instrument used to insufflate the peritoneal cavity
questions.solution:
The Veress Needle is a sterile single-patient use device designed for establishing pneumoperitoneum prior to abdominal endoscopy. The Needle is stainless steel with a spring-loaded stylet that retracts when inserted into the abdomen.

The most common insertion site for the Veress needle is the umbilicus because there is no fat or muscle between the skin and peritoneum. A transumbilical insertion is contraindicated for patients with umbilical abnormalities such as herniation or underlying adhesion.

questions.text: A 15 y girl presents to the OPD with amenorrhea. Her breast and genital exam are normal. She is found to have 5 alpha reductase deficiency. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Male pseudohermaphroditism is a condition of sex differentiation disorders in which the gonads are testes, but the genital ducts and/or external genitalia are incompletely masculinized. This syndrome is caused by a failure of the sequential process in embryonal development of the testis.

Male pseudohermaphroditism can also result from a deficiency of 5α-reductase, which is responsible for the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone.

questions.text: A marker of ovarian reserve is
questions.solution:
Ovarian reserve tests are to assess the quantity as well as the quality of primordial follicles present in the women's ovary. These tests are done to determine how the ovaries will respond to therapy(ovulation induction) in other words it is the assessment of the reproductive potential of the woman.

The Tests Done Are:

  1. Estimation of basal level of serum FSH on D3 and again on D10 following clomiphene citrate challenge test (CCCT): 100 mg orally each day from D5-D9: values >10 IU/L(more than 2SD) indicates poor ovarian
  2. Basal(D3) serum estradiol level > 70-80 pg/mL, poor ovarian
  3. Serum inhibin B(D5): Reduced inhibin B levels(less than 40 pg/mL) are observed in woman with advanced age.
  4. Serum antimüllerian Hormone(AMH): Levels of serum AMH is a good predictor of ovarian stimulation response. Its level also comes with the direct proportion of antral follicle count. Levels of AMH(1ng/mL) declines with age and with poor ovarian reserve. Levels of AMH can be measured any time in the menstrual
    • AMH: AMH is produced by the granulosa cells of the preantral small follicles. Serum levels of estradiol and inhibin B depend on pituitary FSH feedback mechanism. Level of AMH is not dependent on feedback mechanism. This is one of the reasons for which AMH is beingconsidered as a better predictor of ovarian reserve compared to estradiol and inhibin B. Levels of AMH can be measured at anytime in the menstrual cycle. It therefore understood that AMH is qualitative whereas Antral Follicle Count(AFC) is a quantitative marker of ovarian reserve
  5. Antral Follicle Count(AFC) is done by using TVS in early follicular phase inboth the ovaries. AFC reflects the primordial follicular pool in the ovary.
    • AFC more than 6 (2-10 mm size) reflects adequate ovarian follicular
    • AFC, less than 4, indicates poor ovarian reserve and poor response to ovarian stimulation during
    • AFC decreases with

questions.text: A 24 y woman presents with infertility, hirsutism and irregular cycles is diagnosed to have PCOS. All will help in the management except?
questions.solution:
Management of Infertility due to PCOD

  • In PCOD-the basic cause of infertility is anovulation
  • It is easily reversible and treatable using ovulation inducing drugs
  • First advise weight loss(In 5-10% cases-weight loss will cause resumption of ovulation)

1st line drugs-SERM'S

  • Clomiphene citrate-DOC for ovulation induction in PCOS patients
  • Tamoxifen-given to patients who cannot tolerate
  • Raloxifene-Not used for ovulation induction

2nd line agents

  • Gonadotropins:
  • LH/FSH injection

Insulin Sensitizers

Management of Infertility due to PCOD

  • In PCOD-the basic cause of infertility is anovulation
  • It is easily reversible and treatable using ovulation inducing drugs
  • First advise weight loss(In 5-10% cases-weight loss will cause resumption of ovulation)

1st line drugs-SERM'S

  • Clomiphene citrate-DOC for ovulation induction in PCOS patients
  • Tamoxifen-given to patients who cannot tolerate
  • Raloxifene-Not used for ovulation induction

2nd line agents

  • Gonadotropins:
  • LH/FSH injection

Insulin Sensitizers

  • M/C used drug: Metformin
  • Metformin is added when clomiphene citrate is not showing any effect and patient is obese
  • It well help the patient to lose weight
  • M/C side effect-GI upset
  • Most dangerous side effect-Lactic acidosis
  • Metformin is safe during pregnancy

3rd line agents: GnRH agonist

  1. Leuprolide
  2. Guserelin given in pulsatile manner
  3. Nafarelin

questions.text: In a normal sperm analysis, what should be the least % of morphologically normal sperm?
questions.solution:
Semen Analysis (WHO-2010)

Abnormal sperm morphology is termed teratospermia or teratozoospermia.

Kruger and colleagues (1988) developed a detailed characterization of normal sperm morphology, which showed improved correlation with fertilization rates during IVF cycles. Their criteria require careful analysis of the shape and size of the sperm head, the relative size of the acrosome in proportion to the head, and characteristics of the tail, including length, coiling, or presence of two tails. Significantly decreased fertilization rates are seen when normal morphology of the sample falls below 4 percent.

questions.text: Which complication is specific to monochorionic twins?
questions.solution:
• In almost all MC twins, there is a shared circulation in the placenta with different anastomoses. These could be arterial to venous (A-V), venous to venous (V-V) and arterial to arterial (A-A) anastomoses. It has been increasingly known that sharing placenta between twins is not equal.
  • Combination of placental vascular anastomoses and unequal placental sharing predispose MC twins to specific complications such as twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), selective fetal growth restriction (sFGR) and the consequence of co-twin death.

choices.text: Uterotonics for delivery of the placenta

questions.text: Which is not a component of active management of 3rd stage of labor
questions.solution:
AMTSL consists of the following components:

Administration of Uterotonic:

  • Within one minute after the birth of the baby, administer a uterotonic drug, typically oxytocin (10 IU intramuscularly), to promote uterine contractions and reduce the risk of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • If oxytocin isn't available, alternatives include misoprostol, ergometrine, or combinations of these, based on the clinical setting and maternal condition.

Delayed cord clamping

Controlled Cord Traction (CCT):

  • Once the uterus is well-contracted, apply gentle traction on the umbilical cord while supporting the uterus with the other hand to avoid inversion.
  • This step helps safely deliver the placenta and minimizes the risk of retained placenta or hemorrhage. Stop traction if resistance is felt and resume when signs of placental separation are observed.

Assessment of Uterine Tone:

  • After placental delivery, assess the uterine tone by palpating the uterine fundus through the abdomen.
  • Regularly check the uterus every 15 minutes for the first hour postpartum, ensuring it remains firm and contracted. If it feels soft or boggy, a uterine massage can be performed to stimulate contractions if necessary.

Examination of Placenta and Membranes:

  • Examine the placenta and membranes to ensure they are complete. Retained fragments can increase the risk of hemorrhage and infection, necessitating additional intervention.

questions.text: A G2P1 at 36 weeks presents at the antenatal OPD with BP OF 150/105 with urine dipstick of 3+ .You enquire about symptoms of imminent eclampsia. These include all except?
questions.solution:
The following are the ominous symptoms, which may be evident either singly or in combination and are suggestive of imminent eclampsia.

  1. Headache - either located over the occipital or frontal region
  2. Disturbed sleep
  3. Diminished urinary output - Urinary output of less than 400 mL in 24 hours is very ominous
  4. Epigastric pain - acute pain in the epigastric region associated with vomiting, at times coffee color, is due to hemorrhagic gastritis or due to subcapsular hemorrhage in the liver
  5. Eye symptoms - there may be blurring, scotomata, dimness of vision or at times complete blindness. Vision is usually regained within 4-6 weeks following delivery. The eye symptoms are due to spasm of retinal vessels (retinal infarction), occipital lobe damage (vasogenic edema) or retinal detachment. Reattachment of the retina occurs following subsidence of edema and normalization of blood pressure after delivery.

Sudden and generalized edema (and not persistent pedal edema) may indicate imminent eclampsia.

questions.text: The features seen in the karyotype below:
questions.solution:
Klinefelter Syndrome (47XXY)

Pathophysiology

The classic form of Klinefelter syndrome(47XXY) occurs following meiotic nondisjunction of the sex chromosomes during gametogenesis(40% during spermatogenesis, 60% during oogenesis)

Clinical Features

  • Klinefelter syndrome(KS) is the M/C cause of primary testicular failure affecting 1 in 1000 males

In addition to these, men with KS exhibit a number of psychosocial abnormalities like:

In adult life, such males have increased risk of:

Diagnosis

Testicular biopsy shows hyalinised seminifeous tubules and hyperplastic leydig cells.

Pituitary hormones(FSH, LH) are increased and testosterone levels are reduced

Management

Give testosterone

questions.text: Identify this condition
questions.solution:
Staging of Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantitative System

Note: The perineal body is normally at the level of ischial tuberosity. Descent of >2 cm below this level with flattening of the intergluteal sulcus indicates perineal descent.

Symptoms

  • Due to protusion of cervix and uterus into vagina, patient feels something comingdown or out.
  • Groin/back pain(due to stretching of uterosacral ligaments)Q.
  • Feeling of heaviness/pressure in pelvis which is
    • Worse with standing and lifting
    • Worse at the end of the day
    • Is relieved by lying down
  • Decubitus ulcer - on the most dependant part of cervix or vagina. The ulcer occurs as a result of venous congestion and circulatory changes and Q not due to friction created by rubbing of the prolapsed parts with the Q
  • Treatment of decubitus ulcer: Reduction of the prolapse part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine.Q Acriflavine is an antiseptic agent while glycerine is a hygroscopic

Cancer of cervix or vagina is rarely seenQ, even in untreated cases of prolapse

questions.text: Identify the condition:
questions.solution: Bartholin's duct cysts and gland abscesses are common problems in women of reproductive age. Bartholin's glands are located bilaterally at the posterior introitus and drain through ducts that empty into the vestibule at approximately the 4 o'clock and 8 o'clock positions. These normally pea-sized glands are palpable only if the duct becomes cystic or a gland abscess develops.

questions.text: A 21Y G2 presents at 20 weeks. she has brought her USG films which show the following and seeks your opinion. what is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Anencephaly is diagnosed by the absence of cranial vault (calvarium) and telencephalon. Brain tissue is angiomatous.

Early diagnosis is possible at about 13 weeks. The triangular head sign or frog face or Mickey mouse sign on the USG is suggestive of Anencephaly.

Sonographically, the cranial contour may appear abnormal in the first trimester and may resemble a "shower cap" in the late first or early second trimester. The face often appears triangular, and sagittal images demonstrate lack of an ossified cranium. Hydramnios from impaired fetal swallowing is common in the third trimester.

Anencephaly is uniformly lethal. If the pregnancy is continued, perinatal palliative care consultation should be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of secondary amenorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Secondary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menses for three cycles or six months in women who previously had regular menstruation. Identifying the underlying cause typically requires a combination of history, physical examination, and diagnostic testing.

  1. Physiological Causes
    • Pregnancy (most common cause)
    • Breastfeeding (lactational amenorrhea)
    • Menopause or perimenopause
  2. Hypothalamic Causes
    • Functional Hypothalamic Amenorrhea: Often due to stress, weight loss, excessive exercise, or eating disorders.
    • Chronic Illnesses: Conditions like celiac disease or chronic kidney disease can impact hypothalamic function.
    • Infiltrative Disorders: Tumors (e.g., craniopharyngioma), sarcoidosis, or other infiltrative diseases affecting the hypothalamus.
  3. Pituitary Causes
    • Hyperprolactinemia: Can be caused by pituitary adenomas (prolactinomas), medications (e.g., antipsychotics), or hypothyroidism.
    • Pituitary Tumors: Growths that interfere with hormone production, such as non-prolactin-secreting adenomas.
    • Sheehan's Syndrome: Postpartum pituitary necrosis due to severe blood loss during or after childbirth.
    • Empty Sella Syndrome: Pituitary gland is either flattened or small.
  4. Ovarian Causes
    • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): Common cause, associated with irregular menstruation, hirsutism, and metabolic issues.
    • Primary Ovarian Insufficiency (POI): Premature ovarian failure, often due to autoimmune factors, genetic issues (e.g., Turner syndrome mosaicism), or chemotherapy/radiation exposure.
    • Ovarian Tumors: Granulosa cell tumors or other hormone-producing ovarian neoplasms.
  5. Uterine Causes
    • Asherman Syndrome: Intrauterine adhesions or scarring, often secondary to uterine surgeries like dilation and curettage (D&C) or infections.
    • Endometrial Atrophy: Often due to long-term use of hormonal contraception or other endometrial damage.
  6. Endocrine Causes
    • Thyroid Disorders: Both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism can disrupt menstrual cycles.
    • Adrenal Disorders: Conditions like Cushing's syndrome or adrenal tumors that cause excess androgens.
    • Diabetes Mellitus: Poorly controlled diabetes can impact menstrual regularity.
  7. Medications and Lifestyle Factors
    • Medications: Antipsychotics, chemotherapy agents, hormonal contraception, antidepressants, and certain antihypertensives can affect menstrual cycles.
    • Lifestyle: Severe stress, extreme exercise, malnutrition, and rapid weight changes.

Options A,B,C are causes of primary amenorrhea

questions.text: Branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery include:
questions.solution:
Branches of Posterior Division:

  1. Iliolumbar artery
  2. Lateral sacral artery
  3. Superior Gluteal artery

Branches of Anterior Division:

  1. Inferior Gluteal artery
  2. Pudendal artery
  3. Umbilical artery
  4. Middle rectal artery
  5. Superior vesical artery
  6. Obturator artery
  7. Uterine artery
  8. Vaginal artery
